facts.text: Ramdhan Singh, a Bhumihar Brahmin of village Barhiya in Bihar, died in 1872 leaving behind two widows, Mosst. Manrup Kumari and Pan Kumari, and about 1700 bighas of land.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1872 one Ramdhan Singh, a Bhumihar Brahmin, of village Barhiya in Bihar died leaving behind two widows, Mosst. Manrup Kumari and Pan Kumari, and about 1700 bighas of land.

facts.text: Manrup Kumari died in 1923.

anchor.surface_text: Manrup Kumari died in 1923 and Pari Kumari in 1933 Even while Pari Kumari was alive her brother Sunder Singh ,seems to have been managing the estate on her behalf.

facts.text: Pari Kumari died in 1933.

anchor.surface_text: Manrup Kumari died in 1923 and Pari Kumari in 1933 Even while Pari Kumari was alive her brother Sunder Singh ,seems to have been managing the estate on her behalf.

facts.text: Sunder Singh managed the estate of Pari Kumari on her behalf while she was alive.

anchor.surface_text: Even while Pari Kumari was alive her brother Sunder Singh ,seems to have been managing the estate on her behalf. Shortly before her death he managed to get from her a deed of release...

facts.text: Shortly before Pari Kumari's death, Sunder Singh got a deed of release from her in favour of Gaya Singh and Falgu Singh, alleged sons of Ramdhan Singh's daughter Jayanti Kumari.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly before her death he managed to get from her a deed of release in favour of two persons, Gaya Singh and Falgu Singh, alleged to be the sons of Ramdhan Singhs daughter, Jayanti Kumari.

facts.text: Lands were recorded in names of Gaya Singh and Falgu Singh in land revenue proceedings despite objections by nearest reversioners.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of the objections by persons who claimed to be the nearest reversioners of Ramdhan Singhs estate, the lands were recorded in their names in the land revenue proceedings.

facts.text: Reversioners (respondents) filed five suits: T.S. Nos. 53 and 61 of 1934 and 20, 29 and 41 of 1935 for possession of the estate.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the reversioners, who are number the respondents in these appeals, filed five suits, T.S. Nos. 53 and 61 of 1934 and 20, 29 and 41 of 1935 for possession of the estate.

facts.text: In 1936, T.S. No. 37 of 1936 was filed by present plaintiffs 8 to 12, 15, 16 and 18 to 21 and Kunu Babu Singh against Gaya Singh and Falgu Singh, claiming to be nearest reversioners and a custom allowing distant heirs to succeed jointly.

anchor.surface_text: In 1936 another suit, T. S. No. 37 of 1936 was filed by the present plaintiffs 8 to 12, 15, 16 and 18 to 21 and Kunu Babu Singh, uncle of the 11th plaintiff...

facts.text: T.S. No. 37 of 1936 failed.

anchor.surface_text: That suit failed. There-, after, the suit out of which the present appeals arise was filed.

facts.text: Present suit filed by distant relatives claiming special family custom for succession per stirpes among descendants of father, modifying Hindu law rule of nearer excluding remote.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs in the present suit as well as the defendants who are sailing with them are related to Ramdhan Singh in a distant degree... Their claim is based on the plea of a special custom...

facts.text: Parties are descendants of Choudhry Mohkam Singh.

anchor.surface_text: According to the plaint the parties are descendants of one Choudhry Mohkam Singh.

facts.text: Genealogical table in plaint runs into 26 printed pages.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint was accompanied by a genealogical table which runs into 26 printed pages in the paper book.

facts.text: Common ancestor Pran Thakur migrated to Barhiya 500-600 years ago; generally agreed among parties.

anchor.surface_text: evidence has been let in to prove the genealogy from the days of one Pran Thakur who is said to have migrated to the village Barhiya about five to six hundred years ago...

facts.text: Village Barhiya divided into twelve Tarafs named after twelve descendants of Pran Thakur.

anchor.surface_text: The village Barhiya is divided into twelve Tarafs named after twelve of Pran Thakurs descendants.

facts.text: Parties belong to Taraf Ram Charan, family of Ch. Mohkam Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The parties to this suit belong to Taraf Ram Charan but in the plaint it was number the custom of Taraf Ram Charan...

facts.text: Plaintiffs sought to prove 52 instances of custom; Subordinate Judge held 43 proved.

anchor.surface_text: Fifty two instances were sought to be proved on behalf of the plaintiffs. The learned Sub-ordinate Judge who tried the suit held fortythree of them proved.

facts.text: High Court held none of 52 instances proved satisfactorily.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court, however, on an exhaustive review of the evidence, held that numbere of the fiftytwo instances had been established satisfactorily...

facts.text: Supreme Court concluded only 3 instances from Mohkam Singh's family admissible; none proved.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing both the parties... we have arrived at the companyclusion that the only evidence which can be taken into account are the three instances in Mohkam Singhs family.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed for plaintiffs; High Court reversed on 27 July 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated the 27th July, 1959 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree Nos. 326, 332 and 333 of 1948.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are dismissed with companyts, one set hearing fee.

facts.text: Mohkam Singh alive over 150 years ago (before 1818).

anchor.surface_text: Mohkam Singh himself seems to have been alive over 150 years ago.

facts.text: Ext. 23 dated 1818 shows Mohkam Singh died some years before.

anchor.surface_text: The earliest document which we have examined, Ext. 23 of the year 1818, shows that even Mohkam Singh had died some years before that...

facts.text: Custom pleaded: estate of separated issueless male devolves on descendants of his father per stirpes, brothers sharing equally with sons/grandsons of deceased brothers.

anchor.surface_text: The Kulachar or ancient family custom... brothers of the last male owner share the estate equally with the sons and grand-sons of deceased brothers.

issues.text: Is there any Kulachar or ancient family custom in the families of the parties in contravention of the established principle of law of succession as alleged by the plaintiffs in para 5 of the plaint? If so, is it valid and binding on the parties affecting the succession of the heritage left by Ramdhan Singh deceased?

issues.text: What is the scope of the evidence that is admissible to prove the pleaded family custom?

anchor.surface_text: Now on whom does the burden rest and what is the scope of the evidence that is admissible ? The earliest decision on the question regarding proof of custom in variance of the general law is found in Ramalakshmi Ammal v. Sivanatha Perumal Sethuraya  14 Moo. Ind. App. 570 585  to the effect It is of the essence of special usages modifying the ordinary law of succession that they should be ancient and invariable and it is further essential that they should be established to be so by clear and unambiguous evidence.

issues.answer: only instances from Mohkam Singh's family admissible; requires clear unambiguous evidence of ancient invariable usage

arguments.claim: Special family custom (Kulachar) exists in the family of Choudhry Mohkam Singh modifying Hindu law so that estate of issueless separated male devolves per stirpes on descendants of his father, brothers sharing equally with sons/grandsons of deceased brothers.

anchor.surface_text: The Kulachar or ancient family custom or usage with regard to succession which prevails from time immemorial in the family of the plaintiffs and defendants First, Second and Third parties and which has been invariably and strictly followed observed and adhered to by the ancestors of the parties and of which there is a clear consciousness in the family is that when a separated male member of the family dies without any issue, his estate devolves in the first instance on his widow or widows, if there be any, and on the death of the widow or widows as the case may be or on the death of the said separated male members dying without issue and without leaving any widow the estate reverts to the descendants of the father of the said male owner and they take the estate in equal shares per stripes and not per capital and brothers of the last male owner share the estate equally with the sons and grand-sons of deceased brothers.

anchor.surface_text: Issue  6  in the suit regarding this question is also as follows Is there any Kulachar or ancient family custom in the families of the parties in contravention of the established principle of law of succession as alleged by the plain

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only three instances from Mohkam Singh's family admissible per pleadings; none proved by clear unambiguous evidence; parties' conduct inconsistent with custom; oral evidence unreliable without documents.

holdings.text: Evidence to prove pleaded family custom confined to instances in Mohkam Singh's family; evidence from other branches or Pran Thakur descendants inadmissible as beyond pleadings.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing both the parties on the question of the admissibility of the evidence we have arrived at the conclusion that the only evidence which can be taken into account are the three instances in Mohkam Singhs family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint paras 1,2,4,5,7,17,18,20 specify custom in Mohkam Singh family; no reference to Pran Thakur or Tarafs; evidence cannot travel beyond pleadings.

holdings.text: Appeals did not abate wholly upon Manmohini's death due to failure to implead Ghia Devi; estate sufficiently represented by son Raktoo Singh absent fraud or collusion.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that there is nosubstance in the preliminary objection raised on behalf of the respondents and it should be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Some legal representatives suffice for joint/indivisible decree if estate represented; no fraud/collusion; follows Daya Ram, Dolai Molliko precedents.

holdings.text: High Court correctly exercised power under O.41 R.33 in F.A.326 to grant relief to non-appealing parties despite technical defects in F.A.332/333 due to non-impleadment of Nirsu Prasad Singh.

anchor.surface_text: it was open to the Court in F.A. 326 in exercise of its powers under O.41, r. 33 to give all the appellants therein, that is, the respondents in the appeals before this Court, the relief that the appellants in F.A. 326 were entitled to.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree separable combination of individual shares; no conflict; each reversioner entitled to own share; O.41 R.33 applies to readjust rights.

holdings.text: Special family customs modifying ordinary Hindu succession law must be ancient, invariable, and established by clear and unambiguous evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It is of the essence of special usages modifying the ordinary law of succession that they should be ancient and invariable and it is further essential that they should be established to be so by clear and unambiguous evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ramalakshmi Ammal (PC); applied to family customs per Pushpavathi (SC); burden on pleader; consensus/tradition relevant but insufficient without evidence.

holdings.text: Ordinary rule of Hindu law that nearer excludes remote applies absent proof of modifying custom; nearer reversioners (respondents) entitled to estate.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are dismissed with costs, one set hearing fee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custom rejected; propinquity governs; decree for respondents as nearest heirs.

holdings.text: Res judicata from T.S.37/1936 applies to parties therein but court decides on merits as not all distant reversioners were parties.

anchor.surface_text: It was held not proved and as quite a few of the present plaintiffs were parties to that suit, the decision therein would be res-judicata as against them. But we prefer to discuss the matter and decide it on its merits

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are dismissed with costs, one set hearing fee.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; plaintiffs failed to prove the alleged family custom modifying Hindu law of succession; High Court decree upheld in favour of nearer reversioners (respondents).
